conclusion: Use the ideal gas law to find the temperature of the gas in state B.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT.
Since the mass of the gas is constant, the number of moles n is also constant.
Write the ideal gas law for states B and C: P_B V_B = nR T_B and P_C V_C = nR T_C.
Divide the equation for state B by the equation for state C: (P_B V_B) / (P_C V_C) = T_B / T_C.
Rearrange for T_B: T_B = T_C (P_B V_B) / (P_C V_C).
From the p-V diagram: State B: P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 5 x 10^-3 m^3; State C: P_C = 5 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
Temperature at state C, T_C = 300 K.
Substitute values into the equation: T_B = 300 ((2 x 10^5) x (5 x 10^-3)) / ((5 x 10^5) x (2 x 10^-3)).
